title.value: Experts Don’t Cheat: Learning What You Don’t Know By Predicting Pairs
title.justification: This is the title of the paper provided by the user.
title.quote: Experts Don’t Cheat: Learning What You Don’t Know By Predicting Pairs

extractions.description: The paper presents a strategy for training models to estimate the gaps between their predictions and the true underlying data distribution by predicting pairs of responses. This technique helps in identifying and quantifying epistemic uncertainty by allowing the model to 'cheat' by observing one response while predicting the other.

type.justification: The paper demonstrates the proposed methods using empirical experiments and provides results with various datasets and tasks to support the claims.
type.quote: We demonstrate empirically that our approach accurately estimates how much models don’t know across ambiguous image classification, (synthetic) language modeling, and partially-observable navigation tasks, outperforming existing techniques.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on improving uncertainty estimation in predictive models through a novel training strategy involving paired response prediction.
name.quote: We show that second-order calibration is equivalent to ordinary calibration over pairs of responses (y1 , y2 ), and propose a simple modification to standard maximum-likelihood training (“training models to cheat” as in Figure 1) which incentivizes models to become second-order calibrated given sufficient capacity and training data.

name.justification: One of the experiments conducted in the paper involves ambiguous image classification, proving its relevance to this subfield.
name.quote: We demonstrate empirically that our approach accurately estimates how much models don’t know across ambiguous image classification, (synthetic) language modeling, and partially-observable navigation tasks.

name.justification: The paper applies its proposed methodology to a synthetic language modeling task to showcase the effectiveness of the uncertainty estimation technique.
name.quote: We demonstrate empirically that our approach accurately estimates how much models don’t know across ambiguous image classification, (synthetic) language modeling, and partially-observable navigation tasks.

name.justification: The paper includes experiments in partially-observable navigation tasks to validate the performance of the proposed technique in estimating model uncertainty.
name.quote: We demonstrate empirically that our approach accurately estimates how much models don’t know across ambiguous image classification, (synthetic) language modeling, and partially-observable navigation tasks.

name.justification: This model is introduced and used in the empirical experiments within the paper as a method to estimate epistemic uncertainty by allowing the model to cheat.
name.quote: In particular, we propose to directly train a model p̂θY1,Y2|X (Y1 , Y2 |X) to predict paired responses by minimizing the standard cross-entropy loss.

is_contributed.justification: The model is presented as a primary contribution of the research, intended to improve the accuracy of uncertainty estimation.
is_contributed.quote: We show that second-order calibration is equivalent to ordinary calibration over pairs of responses (y1 , y2 ), and propose a simple modification to standard maximum-likelihood training (“training models to cheat” as in Figure 1).

is_executed.justification: The paper includes empirical results obtained by running this model on various tasks and datasets.
is_executed.quote: We demonstrate empirically that our approach accurately estimates how much models don’t know across ambiguous image classification, (synthetic) language modeling, and partially-observable navigation tasks.

is_compared.justification: The model's performance is compared to existing uncertainty quantification methods in the empirical sections of the paper.
is_compared.quote: We demonstrate empirically that our approach accurately estimates how much models don’t know across ambiguous image classification, (synthetic) language modeling, and partially-observable navigation tasks, outperforming existing techniques.

referenced_paper_title.value: Evidential Deep Learning to Quantify Classification Uncertainty
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper by Sensoy et al. is cited in the context of comparing models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Borrow Evidential DL (Sensoy et al., 2018), on the other hand, is underconfident because its objective biases its uncertainty estimates.

name.justification: This model is used as a comparative baseline for measuring uncertainty in the empirical experiments of the paper.
name.quote: Existing techniques for estimating epistemic uncertainty often attempt to estimate how much pY|X could vary given what the model “knows”. For instance, Gaussian processes (Bernardo et al., 1998) and Bayesian neural networks (Goan & Fookes, 2020) impose a prior distribution over the generative process.

is_contributed.justification: The model is not a contribution of this paper; it is used for comparison purposes.

name.justification: This is a common baseline model used in the paper for comparison against the proposed Cheat-Corrected Selection model.
name.quote: Other related strategies include ensembling (Lakshminarayanan et al., 2016), injecting noise into the model or training process (Gal & Ghahramani, 2015; Osband et al., 2021), or predicting a “distribution over distributions” (Sensoy et al., 2018; Malinin & Gales, 2018).

name.justification: This model is used as a comparative baseline for measuring uncertainty about the predictions a model makes, similar to the proposed model.
name.quote: We compare our approach to a variety of existing uncertainty quantification techniques: SNGP Cov. (Liu et al., 2020), which uses spectral normalization and a Laplace random-features approximation to a Gaussian process covariance; Evidential DL (Sensoy et al., 2018), which uses a regularized Dirichlet output to estimate epistemic uncertainty; Epinet (Osband et al., 2021), which models uncertainty by feeding a random “index” input through a fixed “prior” network and a learned corrector.

is_contributed.justification: The model is not a contribution of this paper; it is used for comparison.

referenced_paper_title.value: Simple and Principled Uncertainty Estimation with Deterministic Deep Learning via Distance Awareness
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper by Liu et al. is cited in the context of comparing models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We compare our approach to a variety of existing uncertainty quantification techniques: SNGP Cov. (Liu et al., 2020), which uses spectral normalization and a Laplace random-features approximation to a Gaussian process covariance.

name.justification: The CIFAR-10H dataset is used to evaluate the uncertainty estimation of the proposed models under ambiguous image classification tasks.
name.quote: We compare our approach to a variety of existing uncertainty quantification techniques: ... ECE-2 is second-order calibration error of the variance estimate (best ECE-2 in bold), E[v̂ θ ] is predicted epistemic variance, and E[(p̂θ − p)2 ] is actual grouping error (ideally close to E[v̂ θ ]). ... Our primary evaluation metric is the expected second-order calibration error between the predicted epistemic variance and the actual squared difference between the predicted probability and p(Y |x).
